title: The health and morbidity of friendly society members in the late-nineteenth and twentieth centuries
abstractText:
The award-holders have previously conducted research into the history of morbidity in the UK using the sickness insurance records of the Hampshire Friendly Society (HFS), a small but exceptionally well-administered County friendly society in southern England. This award will enable them to extend their research by focusing more closely on the relationship between individual sickness histories and longevity, covering a longer chronological period, and examining other sources of information about sickness history. 

By the end of the project, they will have created a unique longitudinal dataset containing the sickness histories of  over 6000 individuals from the 1830s to the 1980s. They will use this material to improve their understanding of long-term changes in patterns of morbidity, and extend their analyses of the proximate causes of sickness claims and the relationship between sickness in young adulthood and subsequent mortality.
